text.p: U.S. computer software company Oracle Corp said on Tuesday it had appointed India's NIIT Ltd as a sub-licencee to help NIIT offer systems integration services to a growing market in the Indian corporate sector.

"Under the recently concluded agreement, NIIT will sub-license all Oracle products including core products and ERP (enterprise resource planning) applications suite along with specialised systems integration services," Oracle said in a statement.

NIIT, which is a leading computer education and training company in India, also has interests in computer consultancy and services. Oracle is the world's second largest software company after Microsoft Corp.

Systems integration involves building computer facilities linked to existing equipment and software, or setting up comprehensive computer systems to meet customer needs ranging from purchase to staff training.

"We feel that they (NIIT) offer some unique skills and knowledge of the Indian market," Anil Kaul, managing director of the U.S. company's Indian arm, Oracle India Private Ltd, told a news conference in New Delhi.

The partnership would help NIIT, which has experience in South East Asian countries, offer combinations of computer hardware, software, applications and networking facilities, NIIT official Arvind Thakur said.
Thakur said NIIT was targeting a number of medium-sized and large Indian companies which were ready to make substantial investments in upgrading their computer infrastructure.
NIIT's revenue from systems integration services was expected to grow to 1.0 billion rupees in 1996/97 (October-September), from 350 million rupees in 1995/96, Thakur said.
Kaul said Oracle's agreement with NIIT would not preclude NIIT from offering solutions that might use products from other companies if that helped serve customers better.
"None of us believe in tying people to a particular set of products," Kaul said.
